Destin I watch apt of your videos. I actually am a Captain for NOAA in the Great Lakes Region. A lot of our divers use to quantify coral reefs so this video was very interesting. Please check out Hyperdiver on youtube. We had Hyperdiver on one of our cruises with one of its creators, Arjun. Hyperdiver uses refracted light to identify different corals. I think k you will be super interested in the video and technology used. Take care and keep producing awesome videos.

Heyy, we do that where I'm from on Reef Watch dives. Instead of a square we used hoola hoop with weights.

Hey Destin, this looks like an interesting project with great teaching potential. As a scientific method, however, did you spot the flaw?
Reefs are things with a lifespan: they begin, they grow, they decline, they die.The reason people are interested in filming this is because the Great Barrier is a famous reef. It is famous because it is well established. It is established because it is old. If we monitor all the famous reefs in the world, we should expect that most will be in decline.The ones that are growing are smaller and more importantly, have not yet established a reputation for size.
Monitoring reefs by fame is a selection bias. For valid science you'd need to apply your quadrant method to the whole ocean (or all the world's coastlines.)
4:21 the fish was talking... xD
One problem I find troubling is the unscientific way of describing the enterprise as your goal is to "document the decline in the coral reef" - That's not science; that's propaganda.

I worry a little bit when I hear that a group of scientists are looking for a certian outcome. In this case they are looking for the decline in a reaf. In my own opinion (witch should be taken for what it is worth) scientists should never set out expecting a result. They should be testing for an increase, decrease, or stability of the reaf. When people start testing for an outcome they start inadvertantly twist facts to suit hypothesese and hypothesese to match the facts. I'm not badmouthing this team, or Destin, I just think that the way that scientists approach a problem in recent decades is mildly flawed.

I returned to Green Island when I was 45 to find the same greyish mess you see in this video. It seems there is a fine dust over everything.

Also, because the younger generation can't know what the reef looked, they will not be moved to do anything about it's slow destruction.

Destin, though I like the online assignment you gave us, I would like to make an addendum. I think the best way to convince people that the reefs (or any natural phenomena) are important, isn't just to show them beautiful pictures of it. You have to tell them, "Look, see all of these places? You can go there? This can be your adventure". A lot of times, people see the far off vistas as unattainable, when really, they exist for all of us (assuming we are respectful and responsible towards them).

You are so right about people not caring about the reefs if they have not seen them.  The first time I saw the coral reefs off of Florida my whole point of view changed on how we should view them.  It's like looking at our rain forests. If you have never been into the forest then it just looks like a bunch of trees. Same goes for a reef. It just looks like a bunch of water, until you get under the water

How did you manage that "breathing" of the Diving Mask? It makes the sound not at regular intervals but rather always when you have a break in between words. Like its waiting for you. But how or why should it do that? So my thought was, ist it you yourself that is triggering the noise? And do you need to do it manualy or would it do this by itself after some time. I guess that it's important for you to get the compressed air, so it should happen regardless of your action. And yet it seems to be dependant on it.
...wondering out loud

Also, did you get that diving mask just so you could talk under water instead of dubbing over your footage afterwards? ;)
